entry.title: AI-Assisted Museum Exhibition Classification
entry.content:
AI-Assisted Museum Exhibition Classification: Solving the Reflection Problem

ğŸ“– Background

In many museums, exhibits are often encased in glass display cases, causing reflections that blur images and negatively affect automated image recognition accuracy. This presents challenges for real-time identification and classification, particularly in large museums where manually labeling and managing a large volume of artifacts is both time-consuming and labor-intensive.

To address this issue, we have combined the YOLO (You Only Look Once) object detection model with a reflection removal model to create a solution that can adapt to various museum environments, remove reflection interference, and accurately identify artifacts.

âœ¨ Our Solution

1. Reflection Removal Model

Background

The primary challenge is dealing with reflection. Traditional open-source reflection removal methods are not effective for handling the complex lighting conditions found in museum exhibition halls. Hence, we developed a model that can adapt to non-fixed environments to effectively remove reflections.

Technique

We adopted the Pix2pix GAN (Generative Adversarial Network) as our foundational architecture and incorporated Sobel Features to enhance the modelâ€™s ability to remove reflections. The modelâ€™s goal is to convert images with reflections into clear, reflection-free photos. This specific design allows the model to focus on reflection areas, avoiding the destruction of essential artifact details.

2. Artifact Identification Model

Background

Even after removing reflections, identifying multiple artifacts in a single image remains challenging. To tackle this, we introduced the YOLOv8n object detection model, which specializes in quick and accurate multi-object detection.

Technique

We manually annotated around 2,000 artifact photos, categorizing them into 7 distinct types of exhibits. Using data augmentation techniques (e.g., flipping, scaling, brightness adjustment), we enhanced the modelâ€™s generalization ability. This treatment enables the model to effectively detect and classify artifacts under various lighting conditions and angles.

3. Combining Reflection Removal and YOLO Detection

The reflection removal model and the YOLOv8n model were combined to provide two forms of artifact identification:

  1. Original Identification: Directly applying YOLO detection on the original photo.
  2. Reflection-Removed Identification: Processing the photo through the reflection removal model first, followed by YOLO detection.

By comparing both results, we select the optimal classification to ensure the best performance in various environments.

ğŸ† Results & Achievements

Data Outcomes

  1. V1 Model (Original YOLO): Achieved a classification accuracy of 89% (514/573).
  2. V2 Model (With Reflection Removal): Improved the accuracy to 94.5%, a 1.8% increase over the original model.

Qualitative Outcomes

  1. Focused Attention on Reflections: The reflection removal model accurately identifies and processes reflection areas, improving clarity without damaging artifact details.
  2. Detection Model Performance: The artifact detection model maintains a high level of accuracy in framing and classifying artifacts, even in scenarios with multiple objects.

ğŸ“² App Design

The reflection removal and YOLOv8n models were deployed in a dual-platform application built with Android Studio and Xcode, allowing users to easily capture images of artifacts and receive instant, detailed information.

Core Features

  1. Camera Functionality: Users can easily access the camera to capture images of exhibits.
  2. Image Processing: After capturing an image, the app simultaneously performs reflection removal and classification, displaying the best results.
  3. Results Display: The app displays the classification and additional information for the detected artifacts.

App Screenshots

Initial app screen when openedCamera ready for capturing images
Image after capturingResults after image processing

ğŸ“· Demo

Watch the demo video below:

Click the image above to watch the demo.

ğŸš€ Benefits & Real-World Application

Achievements & Advantages

  • Reflection Removal Model: Improves image recognition accuracy, especially for exhibits behind glass cases.
  • YOLO Multi-Object Detection: Supports multi-object detection with accurate artifact classification.
  • Dual-Platform Support: The app is available on both iOS and Android, ensuring a wide user base.

Practical Application

  1. Museum Usage: The app enables visitors to quickly obtain detailed exhibit information, enhancing the museum experience.
  2. Cultural & Educational: Apart from museums, the app can be expanded to other cultural venues like art galleries, educational institutions, etc.

ğŸ¯ Future Prospects

  1. Model Optimization: Enhance the accuracy and speed of the reflection removal and YOLO models, improving multi-object detection efficiency.
  2. Multi-Language Support: Expand the appâ€™s UI to support multiple languages, providing a friendly experience for users from different regions.
  3. Broader Application Scenarios: Beyond museum guides, the solution can be applied to other object recognition scenarios, such as product photography, academic research, etc.

ğŸ¤ Summary

This project has successfully enabled more automated and precise identification of museum exhibits, paving the way for potential future collaborations with museums and advancing AI technology in the cultural sector. We look forward to exploring new interactive ways of guiding visitors and expanding the value of this solution across industries.

entry.title: CS50 Week 0
entry.content:
What is computer science?

  • Computer science is fundamentally problem solving, but weâ€™ll need to be precise and methodical.

  • We can think of problem solving as the process of taking some input (a problem we want to solve) and generate some output (the solution to our problem).

Representing numbers

  • Decimal system: 10 digits, 0 through 9

  • Binary system: two digits, 0 and 1 (computer using)

    • Each binary digit is also called a bit.
    • In binary, with just two digits, we have powers of two for each place value:
    • Most computers use 8 bits at a time
    • 8 bits = 1 byte

Text

  • The standard mapping, ASCII

  • Unicode: uses more bits than ASCII to accommodate characters, such as letters with accent marks and symbols in other languages.

  • emoji: based on the Unicode standard

  • different companies that create software for their devices will have slightly different images that represent each emoji, since only the descriptions have been standardized.

    • For example, the â€œface with medical maskâ€ 11110000 10011111 10011000 10110111

Images, video, sounds

We just came up with some convention for representing.

  • Color: RGB( common system that we are using)

  • Image: made up of many thousands or millions of pixels( The dots, or squares, on our screens)

    three bytes to represent the color for each pixel

  • Video:sequences of many images, changing multiple times a second to give us the appearance of motion, as a flipbook might.

  • Music: represented by MIDI format.

Algorithms

  • The black box that transforms inputs to outputs contains algorithms, step-by-step instructions for solving problems:

Pseudocode

  • Pseudocode: a representation of our algorithm in precise English (or some other human language):

    1. Pick up phone book
    2. Open to middle of phone book
    3. Look at page
    4. If person is on page
    5. Call person
    6. Else if person is earlier in book
    7. Open to middle of left half of book
    8. Go back to line 3
    9. Else if person is later in book
    10. Open to middle of right half of book
    11. Go back to line 3
    12. Else
    13. Quit

  • Functions: actions or verbs that solve smaller problems

    1. Pick up phone book
    2. Open to middle of phone book
    3. Look at page
    4. If person is on page
    5. Call person
    6. Else if person is earlier in book
    7. Open to middle of left half of book
    8. Go back to line 3
    9. Else if person is later in book
    10. Open to middle of right half of book
    11. Go back to line 3
    12. Else
    13. Quit

  • Conditionals: branches that lead to different paths, like forks in the road.

    1. Pick up phone book
    2. Open to middle of phone book
    3. Look at page
    4. If person is on page
    5. Call person
    6. Else if person is earlier in book
    7. Open to middle of left half of book
    8. Go back to line 3
    9. Else if person is later in book
    10. Open to middle of right half of book
    11. Go back to line 3
    12. Else
    13. Quit

  • Boolean expressions:the questions that decide where we go, which eventually result in answers of yes or no, or true or false.

    1. Pick up phone book
    2. Open to middle of phone book
    3. Look at page
    4. If person is on page
    5. Call person
    6. Else if person is earlier in book
    7. Open to middle of left half of book
    8. Go back to line 3
    9. Else if person is later in book
    10. Open to middle of right half of book
    11. Go back to line 3
    12. Else
    13. Quit

  • Loops:words that create cycles, where we can repeat parts of our program.

    1. Pick up phone book
    2. Open to middle of phone book
    3. Look at page
    4. If person is on page
    5. Call person
    6. Else if person is earlier in book
    7. Open to middle of left half of book
    8. Go back to line 3
    9. Else if person is later in book
    10. Open to middle of right half of book
    11. Go back to line 3
    12. Else
    13. Quit

Scratch

  • Scratch: graphical programming language, where weâ€™ll drag and drop blocks that contain instructions.

  • Scratch categorizes its pieces, each of which might be a function, conditional, or more:
    • Motion: move
    • Events: blocks will activate when something happens
    • Control: only do something if the Boolean expression inside is true
    • Sensing: includes those Boolean expressions, or questions like whether the sprite is touching the mouse pointer
    • Operators: contains blocks that let us do math or pick random numbers, or combine multiple Boolean expressions
    • Variables: will let us store values like words or numbers, and save them with names like x, y, or other full words to describe them.
    • My Blocks: combine multiple blocks ourselves into a new puzzle piece, or function

åƒåŠ æ¨¡æ“¬è¯åˆåœ‹é›–ç„¶ç„¡æ³•å°ä¸–ç•Œæœ‰å¯¦éš›ä½œç‚ºï¼Œä½†å®ƒå‘ˆç¾å¯«å¯¦çš„ä¸–ç•Œé¢è²Œï¼Œå¸¶çµ¦æˆ‘ä¸ä¸€æ¨£çš„è¦–é‡å’Œæ€ç¶­ï¼Œä¹ŸåŒæ™‚è¨“ç·´åˆ°è¡¨é”ã€çµ±æ•´ã€æ€è€ƒã€è‹±æ–‡ã€ç¤¾äº¤ã€é ˜å°è«¸å¦‚æ­¤é¡åœ¨ä»»ä½•é ˜åŸŸçš†ååˆ†é‡è¦çš„å±¤é¢ï¼Œå› ç‚ºå®ƒè®“æˆ‘æ€æƒ³å’Œèƒ½åŠ›æˆé•·å¾ˆå¤šï¼Œæˆ‘å¸Œæœ›èƒ½å°‡å®ƒæ¨å»£çµ¦æ‰€æœ‰äººï¼Œè®“ä»–å€‘ä¹Ÿèƒ½æ„Ÿå—æ¨¡æ“¬è¯åˆåœ‹çš„å½±éŸ¿å’Œé­…åŠ›ã€‚

ä»£è¡¨vs.ä¸»å¸­ï¼ˆå…©è€…å·®ç•°ï¼‰

æ“”ä»»ä»£è¡¨æ“”ä»»ä¸»å¸­

è­°é¡Œäº†è§£ç¨‹åº¦1. è‡ªèº«åœ‹å®¶çš„ç‹€æ³ 2. åœ‹éš›æ•´é«”ç‹€æ³1. åœ‹éš›æ•´é«”ç‹€æ³ 2. åƒèˆ‡çš„å„åœ‹ç‹€æ³ 3. éå¾€åœ‹éš›ä½œç‚º 4. å¯èƒ½çš„è§£æ±ºæ–¹æ¡ˆ
æœƒè­°é–“æŒ‰ç…§è­°è¦èˆ‡å…¶ä»–åœ‹å®¶åˆä½œå¯«å‡ºæ±ºè­°æ–‡è‰æ¡ˆä¸»æŒæœƒè­°ã€æ¨å‹•æœƒè­°é€²è¡Œã€å”åŠ©ä»£è¡¨ã€æŒæ¡è­°æœƒç‹€æ³

è‡ªèº«åå¥½ï¼š

æˆ‘èªç‚ºæ“”ä»»ä¸»å¸­èƒ½å­¸åˆ°çš„æ±è¥¿æ›´å¤šï¼Œåœ¨å¯«èƒŒæ™¯æ–‡ä»¶æ™‚ï¼Œä¸»å¸­éœ€è¦å®Œæ•´æŒæ¡è­°é¡Œçš„æ¯ä¸€å€‹ç´°ç¯€ï¼Œé€²è€Œæ¿ƒç¸®å‡ºèƒ½è®“æ¯ä½ä»£è¡¨çœ‹æ‡‚çš„èƒŒæ™¯æ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œè€Œä»£è¡¨åªè¦äº†è§£è‡ªå·±åœ‹å®¶å³å¯ã€‚æœƒè­°é€²è¡Œæ™‚ï¼Œä¸»å¸­åœ¨å°ä¸Šéš¨æ™‚æœƒé‡åˆ°è¨±å¤šè‡¨æ™‚ç‹€æ³éœ€è¦ç«‹å³å›æ‡‰ï¼Œè€Œä»£è¡¨å¯ä»¥åœ¨å°ä¸‹æº–å‚™å¥½å†ä¸Šå°ã€‚

entry.title: Hello World
entry.content:
Welcome to Hexo! This is your very first post. Check documentation for more info. If you get any problems when using Hexo, you can find the answer in troubleshooting or you can ask me on GitHub.
